job_title: Medical Case Manager in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros:
The office is pretty nice. 
The company name is recognizable locally. 
The employee parties for summer and christmas are fun.
A lot of the people who work there are wonderful folks who care about the community they’re serving.
cons:
Metro is the kind of place to leave you drained and burnt out, neglect to provide appropriate support or resources, and then have the audacity to ask why their employees are dissatisfied and struggling to keep up. Especially in care coordination roles Metro spreads everyone thin due to chronic understaffing and expects single employees to manage well over one person’s worth of work with no concern about the long term consequences of that. 

The turnover rate is incredibly high and there’s no surprise to me now as to why that is. I was warned by others who had worked here previously before I accepted the role and I didn’t listen but absolutely should have. When I left I was the third most senior person on my team at the time and had been here less than a year - huge red flag! 

I cared about my clients and the ways my job allowed me to provide meaningful assistance to people in my community but that can’t make up for the fact that I have never experienced a workplace that was so inflexible and unwilling to support its staff. 

My last several weeks in my role were some of the worst - I made every effort to ensure my clients were appropriately covered and transferred to other staff members and leadership (unsurprisingly) dropped the ball and this did not happen. When I started at Metro a large number of the client’s I received expressed concerns about being transferred constantly from one case manager to another - another massive red flag! It’s not a great look when client’s start to notice your inability to keep people on your teams. 

I am so thoroughly disappointed in Metro as an employer and frankly as a service provider as well. Do better!

review_title: METRO will suck out your soul then blame you for it
job_title: Sexual Health Prevention Specialist in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: get to work with cool people, christmas party and summer beach party, small holiday bonus, office space is clean and organized, HR/onboarding processes are organized
cons: Patients complain that at Metro they're treated like a number, and they're right. Management doesn't care about doing what helps the patients or community, it's all about meeting numbers and getting more grant funding. You won't be respected as an employee, management is threatened if you contribute any good ideas. They will stomp out your passion for the job and once you're burnt out and resentful, wonder why you aren't performing anymore. Prevention staff pay varies highly, and you will get paid more if you are friends with someone in charge. Prevention staff get pushed into doing events and outreach that they have no say about, there's little notice or information provided, and even less organization. Upper executive team is petty and corrupt, they report other competing CBOs to the DOH just to monopolize local opportunities and grant money. They even "steal" community partners from other CBOs just to make a point, ignoring the fact that there are other organizations that could use their resources. Overall a MISERABLE place to work. And if you start speaking up and demanding better working conditions, they will push you out of the job.

job_title: Operations Administrative Coordinator in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: METRO is a great place to work. You will work hard every day, but it is very rewarding. You will get to use your skills every day and learn so much working here. The work life balance is great, and they really respect your time while on and off the clock, and they do not 'punish' you if you use your PTO. If you work hard for them they will work hard for you. Management is smart, dedicated, detailed and goal oriented. METRO is always growing and evolving. The people that work there are smart and fun, and the working environment is really positive.
cons: METRO is a great place and they expect a lot from you. If you work hard this wont be an issue.

job_title: Medical Case Manager in Tampa, FL
pros: Helping those that are in need. The medical case management experience opened other doors for me.
cons: This is an aweful place to work. The CEO and her pet are horrible, conniving and dishonest people. I wouldn't trust them if they were the last people on earth. They under pay you and over work you. I have seen so many good hard working people get fired from this job because their beliefs are different from the person in charge and they chose to not partake in certain yearly festivities that occur in St. Petersburg, Fl...this celebration is big for the leader and if your beliefs don't fit her's you can kiss your job good bye. I can remember waking up every morning praying that God gave me strength to deal with these people. As a case manager you're expected to complete a lot of paperwork per mbr...they limited the amount of paper you could print monthly but continued to increase your caseload. (The CEO would send out nasty emails if you went over your allowed amount) How idiotic is that!? Good luck if u accept this position with them. I promise you will dislike this environment, it's very negative.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Tampa, FL
pros: Staff are great and really connect well with the clients.  The services provided by this organization are much needed in the community.
cons: Management are the worse I have ever worked with or for.  They create an unstable environment where employees are uncertain from moment to moment if they will be fired or praised.  Clients are seen as a numbers game only with them and employees are dispensable.  The Director sends out emails that degrade staff.  The Vice President is seemingly nice, however she is very cut throat and will stab you in the back as she gives you a hug.  She bases her decisions on assumptions that staff are never performing and micro manages every single moment of staff day.  They will promise you a raise and promise to promote you to get you to work for them and then once you are hired they forget their promises.  GET IT IN WRITING!!!!

job_title: Health Care Team Scheduler in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros:
I been working here at Metro for the past 3.5 years now. I came from an medical office in Pasco working as an office manager for 10 years. When I came to Metro, I had a lot of experience under my belt, 
However I realized that I didn’t know much as I thought . I had no idea what Npep, HRT or PREP was.  I came from a different county and this just something we never spoke of. 
This was an different type of medical office that offered all kinds of services.  This job has opened my eyes to so much in life. I love helping others and here at Metro, that’s exactly what 
we all do and love.  At Metro, we are all a big family, nobody is judged and we are all treated equal here.
cons: Nothing at all.

job_title: Behavioral Health Therapist
pros: METRO is like a family. We work hard and the agency as a whole recognizes the effort we all put in. Even during the pandemic, METRO not only cares about making sure our clients are receiving services but that all the employees are being supported.
cons: There have been a lot of changes that occur, as with any agency, and at times can be frustrating. Though it is hard, METRO does the best job it can to keep its employees in the loop and have an understanding for the changes.

job_title: Outreach and Linkage Navigator in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros:
Being presented with the opportunity to be a part of this organization has been nothing short of a life-changing, extremely uplifting experience, on various levels. Metro employees are expected adhere to a standard of excellence in everything that we do, but rest assured that there are more than enough resources, and more than enough support to be able to do this. Fortunately, I have had an extremely knowledgeable, patient, professional, and encouraging team of directors and colleagues surrounding me, guiding me through every challenge I have faced, and assuring that I have a safe, judgement free space to learn and grow not only professionally but personally as well. My team has been extremely helpful with aiding me in growing my skill-set pertaining to my role and others, and has ensured that I am able to provide the highest quality service to my clients and the community we serve and nurture every day. 
With that being said, my training and professional development experience has been everything one would need it to be in order to feel fully prepared to deliver the highest quality service to our surrounding communities. Pertaining to the role itself, saying that I feel blessed to be able to do what I am doing would be an extreme understatement. As an Outreach and Linkage Navigator, many times I have the honor of getting to be one of the first faces our clients see, especially when we go out into community to conduct testing and/or outreach. Understanding the impact this could have on someone’s day, or the possible trajectory of their care experience motivates to give my best effort during every encounter.
 As an Outreach and Linkage Navigator, my role has a few primary functions which include rapid HIV and HCV testing, either in office or out in the field during outreach, assessing client sexual health risk factors and having risk reduction conversations, actively linking clients to any additional services as much as possible including linkage to PrEP, HIV care, primary care or behavioral health services, and assisting the client with navigating obtaining anything else they may need to help alleviate barriers to care, whether that is cost of care assistance, transportation, job and housing assistance, obtaining a phone, or even directing them to local food pantries to help with getting their most immediate needs met, ensuring they are that much more likely to obtain and maintain care/health services. As part of my role, outreach is also a crucial factor in determining how successful we are in engaging potential clients to help them along their health and wellness journey.
In terms of assisting newly or previously diagnosed people living with HIV, one of the most important parts of my role is establishing the client into care, and helping ease that process as much as possible. Whether they are newly diagnosed or have fallen out of care, it can be difficult for anyone to navigate this process, so it is my responsibility to not only obtain proper documentation relating to this, but to help the client find peace of mind through it all, by making sure that they feel seen and heard, and by making sure that they know we care about them as an individual, and want them to have the best experience possible. 
Everything we do at Metro emphasizes a client centered approach, and is at the core of our mission and purpose as an organization. In addition to this, we always aim to seek new, innovative ways to better serve our community every day, pushing the boundaries of what it means to provide quality health and wellness services that are inclusive, relevant, supportive, and represent the lifetime continuum of the people in our Tampa Bay community. Being a part of the Metro family allows me to feel at peace, knowing that the services and experiences I am providing could make someone's day that much better, and bring that much more comfort and happiness to their lives, especially when they may need it most.
cons: Like any office environment, being at a desk working on a computer for extended hours can be tiresome, but it's really just about finding a way to adjust to your settings. Metro is generous with break time however (you can choose between a 30 min or hour long lunch with two additional 15 minute breaks, plus leniency regarding bathroom breaks and trips to the water/coffee machine. Basically, you're never completely tied to your computer.

pros: Great Place , been there for 7 years and  so many things have changed. Getting rid of bad apples was a beginning of clean up. Over 120 employees now diverse. Pay has gone up to market rate. Family feeling. Glad I stayed but if you don't like to work , this is not the place for you.
cons: as we get bigger more structure. Don't know everyone anymore.

job_title: Medical Case Manager in Tampa, FL
pros: The clients really appreciate what you do for them, this makes you feel good inside. Benefits package is very good.
cons:
CEO is the most unprofessional of all the people within the org.
Vice President has similar traits to Judas (will betray you easily, will try to make you feel bad as a person, will find out gossip from other employees about you). VP thinks she is professional but she is far from it, very petty, extremely rude over email.

This organization uses its employees against each other. They use this strategy to sort of keep all employees on a yo-yo.

Favoritism at its finest. If the VP or CEO for whatever reason does not like you, believe me, they will not even say good morning to you. If they do like you they praise you in front of other employees and try to make the other employees feel bad.

Whatever they promise at hire is a lie. There is no room for growth, they load on excessive responsibilities and most of all the VP micro manages everything. This causes instructions from direct supervisors to change daily, very confusing for employee.

Metro does not care about its employees or its client's it's all about the numbers. 

If you are not gay (even if you accept people regardless of sexual orientation) you will have a hard time at this org.

If you are a Christian do not work here. Every true follower of Christ has a hard time working here.

You will feel disgusted going to work here. No happiness, loads of false pretense. This is no place for young professionals. This is where dreams go to die, the grave yard has more character than the St. Petersburg office.
